definition: against orders/to disobey/to refuse to accept orders
life/fate/order or command/to assign a name, title etc

sentences.english: Nowadays，it is an inhumane punishment to flog the disobedient soldiers of sailors.
sentences.chinese: 今天，鞭笞抗命士兵或水手是不人道的懲罰。

sentences.english: Understanding can wait, but obedience can't.
sentences.chinese: 我們可以慢慢了解真相，卻不能拖延抗命。

sentences.english: Sergeant Howard was reduced to the ranks for disregard of orders.
sentences.chinese: 霍華德士官因爲違抗命令而被降爲小兵。

sentences.english: Answer or you may regret your disobedience.
sentences.chinese: 回答，否則你們會爲自己違抗命令後悔的。

sentences.english: There would be time enough later to dwell on acts of defiance and its cost.
sentences.chinese: 以後會有足夠的時間去仔細考慮抗命的行爲及其代價。

sentences.english: Last time I checked, breaking unjust laws is called civil disobedience.
sentences.chinese: 我最後一次檢查，打破不公正的法律被稱爲公民抗命。

sentences.english: The sergeant was degraded to private for the reason of disobeying order.
sentences.chinese: 這個軍官因爲違抗命令被祕密降級了。

sentences.english: The general was relieved of his command .
sentences.chinese: 這位將軍因爲違抗命令被解除指揮權。

sentences.english: Nowadays, it is an inpeoplee punishment to flog the disobedient soldiers ofsailors.
sentences.chinese: 當今，鞭笞抗命士兵或水手是不人道的懲罰。

sentences.english: He was punished for disobeying orders.
sentences.chinese: 他因違抗命令而受到懲罰。

sentences.english: The colonel rebelled in protest over his transfer, saying it amounted to exile .
sentences.chinese: 上校抗命，反對調動，說調動無異於放逐。

sentences.english: Police denied rumors that the captain was punished for defying orders.
sentences.chinese: 否認了那位長官因爲違抗命令而被懲罰的謠言。
約翰因違抗命令而被開除。

sentences.english: We shall drum him out of the corps for insubordination.
sentences.chinese: 我們將因他違抗命令而把他開除出部隊。

sentences.english: He plans on being arrested for civil disobedience.
sentences.chinese: 他做好了計劃，準備爲公民抗命坐牢。

sentences.english: Not all defence doctrines recognize the existence of justifications of disobedience.
sentences.chinese: 並非所有防禦學說都認可有合理的抗命解釋存在。

definition: see 臨陣退縮|临阵退缩[lin2 zhen4 tui4 suo1]
disobedient/to violate the Mandate of Heaven (天命[Tian1 Ming4])
to shrink back as the time for battle approaches (idiom)/to get cold feet
military orders are like mountains (idiom)/a military order must be obeyed
to disrespect one's superiors/to offend one's elders
to abscond/to be absent without leave
to obey an order/to take orders/to accept a state of affairs
to disobey/to defy an edict/to violate/to go against/to run counter to
